nodes.name: GOVERN
nodes.definition: The organization's understanding of AI risks and ability to manage those risks is routinely informed by a diverse team of AI actors, including governance structures, processes, and mechanisms

nodes.name: MAP
nodes.definition: The context is established and risks and impacts of the AI system are mapped and documented

nodes.name: MEASURE
nodes.definition: Identified AI risks and benefits are analyzed, assessed, and prioritized

nodes.name: MANAGE
nodes.definition: AI risks are managed and monitored on an ongoing basis

nodes.name: Organizational AI Risk Awareness and Training
Management and Monitoring of AI Risks
Organizational policies, processes, procedures, and practices across the AI lifecycle are in place to address risks related to the design, development, deployment, use, and operation of AI systems
Personnel roles and responsibilities, and their level of training, are defined and documented to enable appropriate assignment of responsibility and accountability for AI systems
Personnel and third parties involved in the design, development, deployment, use, operation, or assessment of AI systems are provided with training on AI risks and how to manage them
Policies and procedures are in place to address AI risks and benefits to individuals, groups, organizations, communities, society, and the environment
Structures, processes, and resources are in place to address AI risks to individuals, groups, organizations, communities, society, and the environment throughout the AI lifecycle
Organizational processes address AI risks and benefits to individuals, groups, organizations, communities, society, and the environment in the decision-making process for when to deploy AI systems
Organizational processes for the transparent and accountable use of AI throughout the AI lifecycle are implemented

Senior organizational leaders take responsibility for decisions about risks associated with AI systems, and their oversight extends beyond those directly involved in AI system development, deployment, and use
Organizational practices related to policies, procedures, and processes for AI systems are periodically reviewed and updated
AI system performance and impacts, including impacts on individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society, are monitored and reviewed on an ongoing basis
Mechanisms are in place for the workforce, operators, AI designers and developers, and practitioners to report incidents and concerns related to AI systems
Appropriate methods and processes are established to map, measure, and manage AI risks and related impacts
Organizational risk tolerance for AI systems is determined and communicated
Practices and personnel are in place to facilitate regular engagement with relevant AI actors and to maintain awareness about existing and emerging AI-related risks
Organizational mission and relevant legal and regulatory requirements related to AI are understood and documented
Organizational objectives and practices for AI risk management are communicated across the organization
Organizational practices and procedures for utilizing technology, systems, hardware, and software development are aligned with trustworthy AI principles
Mechanisms are in place to seek feedback from those directly affected by an AI system or representative groups
Processes are in place for third parties (e.g., AI system developers, vendors) to report incidents, submit feedback, and seek redress
Processes are in place for external reporting to relevant stakeholders about AI systems and their impacts
Organizational teams are committed to regularly considering input and implementing feedback from those external to the team that makes decisions about the AI system
The intended purpose, objective, and set of tasks, the contexts in which an AI system will be deployed, and relevant organizational policies are established and documented
Interdependencies and interactions between AI systems, system components, data, and human activities are identified, including upstream data sources and downstream uses
Information about the AI system (e.g., current stage in the AI lifecycle, properties, model architecture) is characterized and documented
Information about data used in developing or operating the AI system is documented, including data sources, data processing, data ownership, and data access controls
The AI deployment environment is characterized and documented, including operations infrastructure, integration with existing systems, deployment platforms, and human-AI configurations
AI system tasks and methods are characterized based on their type, complexity, and other relevant characteristics
AI systems are categorized based on the risks and potential impacts they pose to individuals, groups, organizations, communities, society, and the environment
AI system categorization is documented and managed as an organizational asset throughout the AI lifecycle
Benefits, costs, and impacts of the AI system are understood and documented
Benefits, costs, and impacts of the AI system to individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society are documented and balanced with appropriate context
Processes are in place to assess the costs of AI system failure, the acceptable levels and methods for human appeal or fallback to existing systems
Responsible parties and decision rights are identified for determining when an AI system should not be deployed or discontinued
Likelihood and magnitude of each identified impact to individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society are categorized and prioritized
Potential for negative impacts to individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society, including disparate impacts, is considered and documented
Positive and beneficial uses of the AI system, along with potential positive impacts to individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society, are documented
Potential risks and impacts of AI systems are identified and documented, including those related to the misuse of the AI system
Characteristics of trustworthy AI and organizational risk tolerance are taken into account when considering risk of an AI system
Risk tracking approaches are considered and developed to account for long-term and systemic impacts of AI systems
Approaches for measuring and monitoring risks and impacts of AI systems are established, maintained, and applied
AI system performance and impacts, including risks and unintended outcomes, are regularly assessed through manual and automated means
AI systems are regularly monitored and evaluated using metrics that are representative of organizational values and goals
Processes and procedures are followed to measure the performance of AI system components in the context of the intended use and against defined metrics
Results from independent evaluation and assessment of AI systems are documented and included in decisions about their trustworthiness
Testing processes are in place and are informed by representative AI actors throughout the AI lifecycle
Data used in development or operation of AI systems is assessed for quality, representativeness, and relevance
Data used in the development or operation of AI systems are assessed for potential biases
Data provenance is tracked and documented throughout the AI lifecycle
Processes are followed to enhance representativeness and relevance of data in AI systems
Processes and personnel are in place to regularly monitor AI system performance and impacts
Processes are in place for human monitoring of deployed AI systems to detect and respond to changes in performance or impacts
Processes are in place to track and document data provenance, including data source origins, data transformations, and any modifications made to the data
Approaches are in place for regularly tracking incidents that emerge after deployment of AI systems
Feedback process is in place to capture AI system errors or impacts of AI systems on relevant entities
Organizational practices are in place for tracking and documenting errors and implementing corrections to AI system output
Risks and impacts from AI systems are regularly tracked, documented, and updated to inform risk management
Approaches are put in place to track and address identified risks over time
Strategies are developed to address situations where there is insufficient time or resources to assess and manage risks through typical organizational processes
Processes are established to identify potential for unintended consequences of AI use and capabilities for taking appropriate actions when risks exceed threshold
Processes are established to document and track incidents, errors, and unintended outcomes associated with AI systems
Risk controls are implemented and documented to mitigate identified risks
Plans for responding to AI incidents and performance anomalies are developed and implemented
Procedures for responding to AI system incidents or anomalies are followed when they occur
Lessons learned through managing and responding to AI incidents are documented and incorporated into organizational practices
Processes are in place to coordinate between relevant AI actors who provide input throughout the AI incident response process
Mechanisms and processes are in place for periodic human oversight of deployed AI systems
Mechanisms and processes are in place for AI actors to periodically review AI system documentation and reports
Mechanisms and processes are in place to document decisions about when and how to use human-AI configurations, and the appropriate level of human involvement in AI system decisions
Organizational policies are in place to facilitate the meaningful involvement of human beings throughout the AI lifecycle
Mechanisms and processes are in place for humans to appeal or challenge AI system decisions when appropriate
Training and awareness programs are implemented to support operators and end users who interact with AI systems
Approaches and resources are in place to manage AI risks and impacts
Organizational practices are in place to manage impacts to individuals, groups, communities, organizations, and society
Resources are in place to manage AI risks on an ongoing basis
Mechanisms are in place to prioritize deployment of AI systems based on ongoing risk assessments
Organizational policies are in place to facilitate responsible AI system implementation
Processes are in place for the regular review of AI system implementations to identify and address evolving risks
NIST Cybersecurity Framework 2.0
nodes.description: Framework for managing cybersecurity risks

nodes.name: GOVERN
nodes.description: The organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy are established, communicated, and monitored

nodes.name: IDENTIFY
nodes.description: The organization's current cybersecurity risks are understood

nodes.name: PROTECT
nodes.description: Safeguards to manage the organization's cybersecurity risks are used

nodes.name: DETECT
nodes.description: Possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises are found and analyzed

nodes.name: RESPOND
nodes.description: Actions regarding a detected cybersecurity incident are taken

nodes.name: RECOVER
nodes.description: Assets and operations affected by a cybersecurity incident are restored

nodes.name: Organizational Context
nodes.description: The circumstances - mission, stakeholder expectations, dependencies, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements - surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood

nodes.name: Risk Management Strategy
nodes.description: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions

nodes.name: Roles, Responsibilities, and Authorities
nodes.description: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated

nodes.name: Policy
nodes.description: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established, communicated, and enforced

nodes.name: Oversight
nodes.description: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy

nodes.name: Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management
nodes.description: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders

nodes.name: Asset Management
nodes.description: Assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy

nodes.name: Risk Assessment
nodes.description: The cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals is understood by the organization

nodes.name: Improvement
nodes.description: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all CSF Functions

nodes.name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.description: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware and  managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access

nodes.name: Awareness and Training
nodes.description: The organization's personnel are provided with cybersecurity awareness and training so that they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks

nodes.name: Data Security
nodes.description: Data are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information

nodes.name: Platform Security
nodes.description: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability

nodes.name: Technology Infrastructure Resilience
nodes.description: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience

nodes.name: Continuous Monitoring
nodes.description: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events

nodes.name: Adverse Event Analysis
nodes.description: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents

nodes.name: Incident Management
nodes.description: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed

nodes.name: Incident Analysis
nodes.description: Investigations are conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities

nodes.name: Incident Response Reporting and Communication
nodes.description: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies

nodes.name: Incident Mitigation
nodes.description: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event and mitigate its effects

nodes.name: Incident Recovery Plan Execution
nodes.description: Restoration activities are performed to ensure operational availability of systems and services affected by cybersecurity incidents

nodes.name: Incident Recovery Communication
nodes.description: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties
The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management
nodes.example: Share the organization's mission (e.g., through vision and mission statements, marketing, and service strategies) to provide a basis for identifying risks that may impede that mission

nodes.description: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
nodes.example: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)

nodes.description: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity - including privacy and civil liberties obligations - are understood and managed
nodes.example: Determine a process to track and manage legal and regulatory requirements regarding protection of individuals' information (e.g., Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, California Consumer Privacy Act, General Data Protection Regulation)

nodes.description: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are understood and communicated
nodes.example: Establish criteria for determining the criticality of capabilities and services as viewed by internal and external stakeholders

nodes.description: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated
nodes.example: Create an inventory of the organization's dependencies on external resources (e.g., facilities, cloud-based hosting providers) and their relationships to organizational assets and business functions

nodes.description: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
nodes.example: Update near-term and long-term cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of annual strategic planning and when major changes occur

nodes.description: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained
nodes.example: Determine and communicate risk appetite statements that convey expectations about the appropriate level of risk for the organization

nodes.description: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes
nodes.example: Aggregate and manage cybersecurity risks alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., compliance, financial, operational, regulatory, reputational, safety)

nodes.description: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated
nodes.example: Specify criteria for accepting and avoiding cybersecurity risk for various classifications of data

nodes.description: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties
nodes.example: Determine how to update senior executives, directors, and management on the organization's cybersecurity posture at agreed-upon intervals

nodes.description: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated
nodes.example: Establish criteria for using a quantitative approach to cybersecurity risk analysis, and specify probability and exposure formulas

nodes.description: Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions
nodes.example: Define and communicate guidance and methods for identifying opportunities and including them in risk discussions (e.g., strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats [SWOT] analysis)

nodes.description: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving
nodes.example: Leaders (e.g., directors) agree on their roles and responsibilities in developing, implementing, and assessing the organization's cybersecurity strategy

nodes.description: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced
nodes.example: Document risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

nodes.description: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles, responsibilities, and policies
nodes.example: Conduct periodic management reviews to ensure that those given cybersecurity risk management responsibilities have the necessary authority

nodes.description: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices
nodes.example: Integrate cybersecurity risk management considerations into human resources processes (e.g., personnel screening, onboarding, change notification, offboarding)

nodes.description: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced
nodes.example: Create, disseminate, and maintain an understandable, usable risk management policy with statements of management intent, expectations, and direction

nodes.description: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission
nodes.example: Update policy based on periodic reviews of cybersecurity risk management results to ensure that policy and supporting processes and procedures adequately maintain risk at an acceptable level

nodes.description: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction
nodes.example: Measure how well the risk management strategy and risk results have helped leaders make decisions and achieve organizational objectives

nodes.description: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks
nodes.example: Review audit findings to confirm whether the existing cybersecurity strategy has ensured compliance with internal and external requirements

nodes.description: Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed
nodes.example: Review key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure that organization-wide policies and procedures achieve objectives

nodes.description: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
nodes.example: Establish a strategy that expresses the objectives of the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program

nodes.description: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally
nodes.example: Identify one or more specific roles or positions that will be responsible and accountable for planning, resourcing, and executing cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities

nodes.description: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes
nodes.example: Identify areas of alignment and overlap with cybersecurity and enterprise risk management

nodes.description: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality
nodes.example: Develop criteria for supplier criticality based on, for example, the sensitivity of data processed or possessed by suppliers, the degree of access to the organization's systems, and the importance of the products or services to the organization's mission

nodes.description: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties
nodes.example: Establish security requirements for suppliers, products, and services commensurate with their criticality level and potential impact if compromised

nodes.description: Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships
nodes.example: Perform thorough due diligence on prospective suppliers that is consistent with procurement planning and commensurate with the level of risk, criticality, and complexity of each supplier relationship

nodes.description: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship
nodes.example: Adjust assessment formats and frequencies based on the third party's reputation and the criticality of the products or services they provide

nodes.description: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities
nodes.example: Define and use rules and protocols for reporting incident response and recovery activities and the status between the organization and its suppliers

nodes.description: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle
nodes.example: Policies and procedures require provenance records for all acquired technology products and services

nodes.description: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement
nodes.example: Establish processes for terminating critical relationships under both normal and adverse circumstances

nodes.description: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain inventories for all types of hardware, including IT, IoT, OT, and mobile devices

nodes.description: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain inventories for all types of software and services, including commercial-off-the-shelf, open-source, custom applications, API services, and cloud-based applications and services

nodes.description: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows within the organization's wired and wireless networks

nodes.description: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained
nodes.example: Inventory all external services used by the organization, including third-party infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings; APIs; and other externally hosted application services

nodes.description: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission
nodes.example: Define criteria for prioritizing each class of assets

nodes.description: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain a list of the designated data types of interest (e.g., personally identifiable information, protected health information, financial account numbers, organization intellectual property, operational technology data)

nodes.description: Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles
nodes.example: Integrate cybersecurity considerations throughout the life cycles of systems, hardware, software, and services

nodes.description: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded
nodes.example: Use vulnerability management technologies to identify unpatched and misconfigured software

nodes.description: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
nodes.example: Configure cybersecurity tools and technologies with detection or response capabilities to securely ingest cyber threat intelligence feeds

nodes.description: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded
nodes.example: Use cyber threat intelligence to maintain awareness of the types of threat actors likely to target the organization and the TTPs they are likely to use

nodes.description: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded
nodes.example: Business leaders and cybersecurity risk management practitioners work together to estimate the likelihood and impact of risk scenarios and record them in risk registers

nodes.description: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization
nodes.example: Develop threat models to better understand risks to the data and identify appropriate risk responses

nodes.description: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated
nodes.example: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for deciding whether to accept, transfer, mitigate, or avoid risk

nodes.description: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked
nodes.example: Implement and follow procedures for the formal documentation, review, testing, and approval of proposed changes and requested exceptions

nodes.description: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established
nodes.example: Conduct vulnerability information sharing between the organization and its suppliers following the rules and protocols defined in contracts

nodes.description: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use
nodes.example: Assess the authenticity and cybersecurity of critical technology products and services prior to acquisition and use

nodes.description: Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition
nodes.example: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements, including the supply chain

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from evaluations
nodes.example: Perform self-assessments of critical services that take current threats and TTPs into consideration

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties
nodes.example: Identify improvements for future incident response activities based on findings from incident response assessments (e.g., tabletop exercises and simulations, tests, internal reviews, independent audits)

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities
nodes.example: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with suppliers

nodes.description: Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved
nodes.example: Establish contingency plans (e.g., incident response, business continuity, disaster recovery) for responding to and recovering from adverse events that can interfere with operations, expose confidential information, or otherwise endanger the organization's mission and viability

nodes.description: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization
nodes.example: Initiate requests for new access or additional access for employees, contractors, and others, and track, review, and fulfill the requests, with permission from system or data owners when needed

nodes.description: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions
nodes.example: Verify a person's claimed identity at enrollment time using government-issued identity credentials (e.g., passport, visa, driver's license)

nodes.description: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated
nodes.example: Require multifactor authentication

nodes.description: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified
nodes.example: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information through single sign-on systems

nodes.description: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
nodes.example: Review logical and physical access privileges periodically and whenever someone changes roles or leaves the organization, and promptly rescind privileges that are no longer needed

nodes.description: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Use security guards, security cameras, locked entrances, alarm systems, and other physical controls to monitor facilities and restrict access

nodes.description: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
nodes.example: Provide basic cybersecurity awareness and training to employees, contractors, partners, suppliers, and all other users of the organization's non-public resources

nodes.description: Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
nodes.example: Identify the specialized roles within the organization that require additional cybersecurity training, such as physical and cybersecurity personnel, finance personnel, senior leadership, and anyone with access to business-critical data

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected
nodes.example: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of stored data in files, databases, virtual machine disk images, container images, and other resources

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected
nodes.example: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of network communications

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected
nodes.example: Remove data that must remain confidential (e.g., from processors and memory) as soon as it is no longer needed

nodes.description: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested
nodes.example: Continuously back up critical data in near-real-time, and back up other data frequently at agreed-upon schedules

nodes.description: Configuration management practices are established and applied
nodes.example: Establish, test, deploy, and maintain hardened baselines that enforce the organization's cybersecurity policies and provide only essential capabilities (i.e., principle of least functionality)

nodes.description: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Perform routine and emergency patching within the timeframes specified in the vulnerability management plan

nodes.description: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Replace hardware when it lacks needed security capabilities or when it cannot support software with needed security capabilities

nodes.description: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring
nodes.example: Configure all operating systems, applications, and services (including cloud-based services) to generate log records

nodes.description: Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented
nodes.example: When risk warrants it, restrict software execution to permitted products only or deny the execution of prohibited and unauthorized software

nodes.description: Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle
nodes.example: Protect all components of organization-developed software from tampering and unauthorized access

nodes.description: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage
nodes.example: Logically segment organization networks and cloud-based platforms according to trust boundaries and platform types (e.g., IT, IoT, OT, mobile, guests), and permit required communications only between segments

nodes.description: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats
nodes.example: Protect organizational equipment from known environmental threats, such as flooding, fire, wind, and excessive heat and humidity

nodes.description: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
nodes.example: Avoid single points of failure in systems and infrastructure

nodes.description: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained
nodes.example: Monitor usage of storage, power, compute, network bandwidth, and other resources

nodes.description: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor DNS, BGP, and other network services for adverse events

nodes.description: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor logs from physical access control systems (e.g., badge readers) to find unusual access patterns (e.g., deviations from the norm) and failed access attempts

nodes.description: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Use behavior analytics software to detect anomalous user activity to mitigate insider threats

nodes.description: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor remote and onsite administration and maintenance activities that external providers perform on organizational systems

nodes.description: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor email, web, file sharing, collaboration services, and other common attack vectors to detect malware, phishing, data leaks and exfiltration, and other adverse events

nodes.description: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities
nodes.example: Use security information and event management (SIEM) or other tools to continuously monitor log events for known malicious and suspicious activity

nodes.description: Information is correlated from multiple sources
nodes.example: Constantly transfer log data generated by other sources to a relatively small number of log servers

nodes.description: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood
nodes.example: Use SIEMs or other tools to estimate impact and scope, and review and refine the estimates

nodes.description: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools
nodes.example: Use cybersecurity software to generate alerts and provide them to the security operations center (SOC), incident responders, and incident response tools

nodes.description: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis
nodes.example: Securely provide cyber threat intelligence feeds to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

nodes.description: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria
nodes.example: Apply incident criteria to known and assumed characteristics of activity in order to determine whether an incident should be declared

nodes.description: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared
nodes.example: Detection technologies automatically report confirmed incidents

nodes.description: Incident reports are triaged and validated
nodes.example: Preliminarily review incident reports to confirm that they are cybersecurity-related and necessitate incident response activities

nodes.description: Incidents are categorized and prioritized
nodes.example: Further review and categorize incidents based on the type of incident (e.g., data breach, ransomware, DDoS, account compromise)

nodes.description: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed
nodes.example: Track and validate the status of all ongoing incidents

nodes.description: The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied
nodes.example: Apply incident recovery criteria to known and assumed characteristics of the incident to determine whether incident recovery processes should be initiated

nodes.description: Analysis is performed to establish what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident
nodes.example: Determine the sequence of events that occurred during the incident and which assets and resources were involved in each event

nodes.description: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved
nodes.example: Require each incident responder and others (e.g., system administrators, cybersecurity engineers) who perform incident response tasks to record their actions and make the record immutable

nodes.description: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved
nodes.example: Collect, preserve, and safeguard the integrity of all pertinent incident data and metadata (e.g., data source, date/time of collection) based on evidence preservation and chain-of-custody procedures

nodes.description: An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated
nodes.example: Review other potential targets of the incident to search for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

nodes.description: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents
nodes.example: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures after discovering a data breach incident, including notifying affected customers

nodes.description: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders
nodes.example: Securely share information consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

nodes.description: Incidents are contained
nodes.example: Cybersecurity technologies (e.g., antivirus software) and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform containment actions

nodes.description: Incidents are eradicated
nodes.example: Cybersecurity technologies and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform eradication actions

nodes.description: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process
nodes.example: Begin recovery procedures during or after incident response processes

nodes.description: Recovery actions are selected, scoped, prioritized, and performed
nodes.example: Select recovery actions based on the criteria defined in the incident response plan and available resources

nodes.description: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration
nodes.example: Check restoration assets for indicators of compromise, file corruption, and other integrity issues before use

nodes.description: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms
nodes.example: Use business impact and system categorization records (including service delivery objectives) to validate that essential services are restored in the appropriate order

nodes.description: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed
nodes.example: Check restored assets for indicators of compromise and remediation of root causes of the incident before production use

nodes.description: The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed
nodes.example: Prepare an after-action report that documents the incident itself, the response and recovery actions taken, and lessons learned

nodes.description: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders
nodes.example: Securely share recovery information, including restoration progress, consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

nodes.description: Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging
nodes.example: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures for recovering from a data breach incident

nodes.full_name: A Tool for Improving Privacy through Enterprise Risk Management - Version 1.1
nodes.purpose: Enhance privacy engineering practices supporting privacy by design concepts in AI systems
nodes.name: NIST Privacy Framework 1.1
Identify-P
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced data lifecycle management, AI data processing identification
nodes.definition: Develop the organizational understanding to manage privacy risk for individuals arising from data processing
nodes.primary_focus: Data processing understanding, privacy risk identification, ecosystem mapping

nodes.name: Govern-P
nodes.v11_updates: Standalone governance capabilities, enhanced organizational accountability
nodes.definition: Develop and implement the organizational governance structure to enable an ongoing understanding of the organization's risk management priorities informed by privacy risk
nodes.primary_focus: Governance structure, policies, risk management strategy, organizational accountability

nodes.name: Control-P
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific control mechanisms, enhanced individual empowerment
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations or individuals to manage data with sufficient granularity to manage privacy risks
nodes.primary_focus: Data processing management, individual empowerment, disassociated processing

nodes.name: Communicate-P
nodes.v11_updates: AI transparency requirements, enhanced stakeholder communication
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations and individuals to have a reliable understanding and engage in dialogue about data processing and privacy risks
nodes.primary_focus: Transparency, stakeholder communication, data processing awareness

nodes.name: Protect-P
nodes.v11_updates: Aligned with CSF 2.0 Protect function, enhanced data protection measures
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate data processing safeguards to prevent cybersecurity-related privacy events
nodes.primary_focus: Cybersecurity-related privacy protection, data safeguards, technical controls

nodes.name: Inventory and Mapping
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced AI data inventory and lifecycle mapping

nodes.name: Business Environment
nodes.v11_updates: AI ecosystem stakeholder identification

nodes.name: Risk Assessment
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific risk assessment methodologies

nodes.name: Data Processing Ecosystem Risk Management
nodes.v11_updates: AI supply chain and ecosystem risk management

nodes.name: Governance Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.v11_updates: Standalone governance without CSF dependency

nodes.name: Risk Management Strategy
nodes.v11_updates: AI risk tolerance and strategy frameworks

nodes.name: Awareness and Training
nodes.v11_updates: AI privacy training and awareness programs

nodes.name: Monitoring and Review
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced accountability and responsibility tracking

nodes.name: Organizational Oversight
nodes.v11_updates: New category for enhanced organizational accountability

nodes.name: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific data processing controls

nodes.name: Data Processing Management
nodes.v11_updates: AI data management and individual empowerment controls

nodes.name: Disassociated Processing
nodes.v11_updates: AI privacy-preserving techniques and disassociation

nodes.name: Communication Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.v11_updates: AI transparency and explainability communication

nodes.name: Data Processing Awareness
nodes.v11_updates: AI processing awareness and stakeholder communication

nodes.name: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.v11_updates: Aligned with CSF 2.0 Protect function structure

nodes.name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced access control aligned with CSF 2.0

nodes.name: Data Security
nodes.v11_updates: AI data protection and cybersecurity alignment

nodes.name: Maintenance
nodes.v11_updates: AI system maintenance and updates

nodes.name: Protective Technology
nodes.v11_updates: AI-aware protective technologies

nodes.name: Systems/products/services that process data are inventoried including AI systems
nodes.v11_updates: Explicit inclusion of AI systems in inventory

nodes.name: Data processing is mapped throughout the data lifecycle including AI model training and inference
nodes.v11_updates: AI model training and inference lifecycle mapping

nodes.name: Potential problematic data actions including AI-specific privacy risks are identified
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific privacy risk identification (data reconstruction, bias, etc.)

nodes.name: AI supply chain and data processing ecosystem privacy risks are identified
nodes.v11_updates: New focus on AI supply chain privacy risks

nodes.name: Organizational privacy values and policies are established including AI governance principles
nodes.v11_updates: Standalone privacy governance, AI governance integration

nodes.name: Organizational risk tolerance is determined including AI privacy risk thresholds
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific privacy risk tolerance frameworks

nodes.name: The workforce is informed and trained on privacy responsibilities including AI privacy risks
nodes.v11_updates: AI privacy training and awareness programs

nodes.name: Senior leadership provides oversight and accountability for privacy and AI governance decisions
nodes.v11_updates: New subcategory for enhanced organizational accountability

nodes.name: Data elements can be accessed for review including AI-generated insights
nodes.v11_updates: AI-generated data and insights accessibility

nodes.name: Data are processed to limit observability and linkability using privacy-preserving AI techniques
nodes.v11_updates: Privacy-preserving AI techniques (differential privacy, federated learning)

nodes.name: Data processing policies address AI system controls and individual empowerment
nodes.v11_updates: AI-specific data processing controls and policies

nodes.name: Mechanisms for communicating data processing including AI system operations are established
nodes.v11_updates: AI transparency and explainability communication requirements

nodes.name: Impacted individuals are notified about privacy breaches including AI-related incidents
nodes.v11_updates: AI-related privacy incident notification

nodes.name: Communication policies address AI transparency and stakeholder engagement requirements
nodes.v11_updates: AI transparency policies and stakeholder communication

nodes.name: Identities and credentials are managed for authorized access to AI systems and data
nodes.v11_updates: AI system access control aligned with CSF 2.0

nodes.name: Data-at-rest are protected including AI training datasets and model parameters
nodes.v11_updates: AI training data and model protection

nodes.name: AI-aware protective technologies safeguard data processing and prevent privacy attacks
nodes.v11_updates: AI-aware protective technologies for privacy attack prevention

nodes.name: Data Reconstruction Attacks
nodes.description: AI models may enable reconstruction of training data or reveal sensitive information through model inversion attacks

nodes.name: Prompt Injection Vulnerabilities
nodes.description: Malicious inputs that manipulate AI systems to reveal private information or bypass privacy controls

nodes.name: Membership Inference Attacks
nodes.description: Ability to determine if specific data points were used in AI model training, potentially revealing sensitive information

nodes.name: Statistical and Cognitive Bias
nodes.description: AI-assisted decisions that exhibit unfair bias affecting individuals or groups, leading to discriminatory outcomes

nodes.name: PII Exposure in Training Data
nodes.description: Personal information inadvertently included in AI training datasets, potentially exposed through model outputs

nodes.name: Deepfake and Likeness Rights
nodes.description: AI generation of synthetic content that violates individual likeness rights or creates misleading representations

nodes.name: Predictability
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced focus on AI explainability and predictable AI system behavior
nodes.definition: Enabling reliable assumptions by individuals, owners, and operators about data and their processing by systems including AI systems

nodes.name: Manageability
nodes.v11_updates: AI data governance and model output management capabilities
nodes.definition: Providing capability for granular administration of data including AI-generated data and model outputs

nodes.name: Disassociability
nodes.v11_updates: Privacy-preserving AI techniques (federated learning, differential privacy, secure multi-party computation)
nodes.definition: Enabling processing of data without association to individuals beyond operational requirements using privacy-preserving AI techniques

nodes.privacy_risk_management: Ad hoc and reactive privacy risk management with limited AI risk awareness
nodes.name: Partial
nodes.v11_updates: Enhanced AI risk awareness criteria and AI governance capabilities assessment

nodes.privacy_risk_management: Management-approved practices informed by risk assessments including AI privacy risk evaluation
nodes.name: Risk Informed
nodes.v11_updates: AI risk assessment integration and AI privacy expertise development

nodes.privacy_risk_management: Formally approved privacy policies including comprehensive AI governance framework
nodes.name: Repeatable
nodes.v11_updates: Mature AI governance and oversight capabilities with specialized AI privacy expertise

nodes.privacy_risk_management: Continuous improvement with advanced privacy-preserving AI technologies
nodes.name: Adaptive
nodes.v11_updates: Advanced AI privacy technologies and adaptive AI governance with continuous innovation

nodes.full_title: A Tool for Improving Privacy through Enterprise Risk Management
nodes.purpose: Enable better privacy engineering practices that support privacy by design concepts
nodes.name: NIST Privacy Framework 1.0
Identify-P
nodes.key_activities: Inventory data processing, assess risks, understand ecosystem
nodes.definition: Develop the organizational understanding to manage privacy risk for individuals arising from data processing
nodes.primary_focus: Understanding data processing and privacy risks

nodes.name: Govern-P
nodes.key_activities: Establish policies, define risk tolerance, provide training
nodes.definition: Develop and implement the organizational governance structure to enable an ongoing understanding of the organizations risk management priorities that are informed by privacy risk

nodes.name: Control-P
nodes.key_activities: Manage data processing, enable individual control, implement disassociation
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations or individuals to manage data with sufficient granularity to manage privacy risks

nodes.name: Communicate-P
nodes.key_activities: Communicate processing practices, provide transparency mechanisms
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations and individuals to have a reliable understanding and engage in a dialogue about how data are processed and associated privacy risks
nodes.primary_focus: Transparency and communication about data processing

nodes.name: Protect-P
nodes.key_activities: Implement data protection, access control, security safeguards
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate data processing safeguards

nodes.name: Systems/products/services that process data are inventoried.

Owners or operators (e.g., the organization or third parties such as service providers, partners, customers, and developers) and their roles with respect to the systems/products/services and components (e.g., internal or external) that process data are inventoried.
Categories of individuals (e.g., customers, employees or prospective employees, consumers) whose data are being processed are inventoried.
Data actions of the systems/products/services are inventoried.
The purposes for the data actions are inventoried.
Data elements within the data actions are inventoried.
The data processing environment is identified (e.g., geographic location, internal, cloud, third parties).

Data processing is mapped, illustrating the data actions and associated data elements for systems/products/services, including components; roles of the component owners/operators; and interactions of individuals or third parties with the systems/products/services.
The organization�s role(s) in the data processing ecosystem are identified and communicated.
Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated.
Systems/products/services that support organizational priorities are identified and key requirements communicated.

Contextual factors related to the systems/products/services and the data actions are identified (e.g., individuals� demographics and privacy interests or perceptions, data sensitivity and/or types, visibility of data processing to individuals and third parties).
Data analytic inputs and outputs are identified and evaluated for bias.
Potential problematic data actions and associated problems are identified.
Problematic data actions, likelihoods, and impacts are used to determine and prioritize risk.
Risk responses are identified, prioritized, and implemented.
Data processing ecosystem risk management policies, processes, and procedures are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.

Data processing ecosystem parties (e.g., service providers, customers, partners, product manufacturers, application developers) are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a privacy risk assessment process.
Contracts with data processing ecosystem parties are used to implement appropriate measures designed to meet the objectives of an organization�s privacy program.
Interoperability frameworks or similar multi-party approaches are used to manage data processing ecosystem privacy risks.

Data processing ecosystem parties are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual, interoperability framework, or other obligations.

Organizational privacy values and policies (e.g., conditions on data processing such as data uses or retention periods, individuals� prerogatives with respect to data processing) are established and communicated.
Processes to instill organizational privacy values within system/product/service development and operations are established and in place.
Roles and responsibilities for the workforce are established with respect to privacy.
Privacy roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with third-party stakeholders (e.g., service providers, customers, partners).
Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding privacy are understood and managed.
Governance and risk management policies, processes, and procedures address privacy risks.
Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.
Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed.
The organization�s determination of risk tolerance is informed by its role(s) in the data processing ecosystem.
The workforce is informed and trained on its roles and responsibilities.
Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities.
Privacy personnel understand their roles and responsibilities.
Third parties (e.g., service providers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities.

Privacy risk is re-evaluated on an ongoing basis and as key factors, including the organization�s business environment (e.g., introduction of new technologies), governance (e.g., legal obligations, risk tolerance), data processing, and systems/products/services change.
Privacy values, policies, and training are reviewed and any updates are communicated.
Policies, processes, and procedures for assessing compliance with legal requirements and privacy policies are established and in place.
Policies, processes, and procedures for communicating progress on managing privacy risks are established and in place.

Policies, processes, and procedures are established and in place to receive, analyze, and respond to problematic data actions disclosed to the organization from internal and external sources (e.g., internal discovery, privacy researchers, professional events).
Policies, processes, and procedures incorporate lessons learned from problematic data actions.

Policies, processes, and procedures for receiving, tracking, and responding to complaints, concerns, and questions from individuals about organizational privacy practices are established and in place.

Policies, processes, and procedures for authorizing data processing (e.g., organizational decisions, individual consent), revoking authorizations, and maintaining authorizations are established and in place.

nodes.name: Data elements can be accessed for review.

Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy and incorporating the principle of data minimization.
Technical measures implemented to manage data processing are tested and assessed.
Stakeholder privacy preferences are included in algorithmic design objectives and outputs are evaluated against these preferences.
Data are processed to limit observability and linkability (e.g., data actions take place on local devices, privacy-preserving cryptography).
Data are processed to limit the identification of individuals (e.g., de-identification privacy techniques, tokenization).
Data are processed to limit the formulation of inferences about individuals� behavior or activities (e.g., data processing is decentralized, distributed architectures).
System or device configurations permit selective collection or disclosure of data elements.
Attribute references are substituted for attribute values.
Transparency policies, processes, and procedures for communicating data processing purposes, practices, and associated privacy risks are established and in place.
Roles and responsibilities (e.g., public relations) for communicating data processing purposes, practices, and associated privacy risks are established.

Mechanisms (e.g., notices, internal or public reports) for communicating data processing purposes, practices, associated privacy risks, and options for enabling individuals� data processing preferences and requests are established and in place.
Mechanisms for obtaining feedback from individuals (e.g., surveys or focus groups) about data processing and associated privacy risks are established and in place.
System/product/service design enables data processing visibility.
Records of data disclosures and sharing are maintained and can be accessed for review or transmission/disclosure.
Data corrections or deletions can be communicated to individuals or organizations (e.g., data sources) in the data processing ecosystem.
Data provenance and lineage are maintained and can be accessed for review or transmission/disclosure.
Impacted individuals and organizations are notified about a privacy breach or event.
Individuals are provided with mitigation mechanisms (e.g., credit monitoring, consent withdrawal, data alteration or deletion) to address impacts of problematic data actions.
A baseline configuration of information technology is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g., concept of least functionality).

nodes.name: Policy and Procedures
nodes.description:
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:

1. [Selection (one or more): Organization-level; Mission/business process-level; System-level] access control policy that:

(a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
(b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the access control policy and the associated access controls;
b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the access control policy and procedures; and
c. Review and update the current access control:

1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].

nodes.name: Account Management
Account Management | Automated System Account Management
nodes.description: Support the management of system accounts using [Assignment: organization-defined automated mechanisms].

nodes.name: Account Management | Automated Temporary and Emergency Account Management
nodes.description: Automatically [Selection: remove; disable] temporary and emergency accounts after [Assignment: organization-defined time period for each type of account].

nodes.name: Account Management | Disable Accounts
Account Management | Automated Audit Actions
nodes.description: Automatically audit account creation, modification, enabling, disabling, and removal actions.

nodes.name: Account Management | Inactivity Logout
nodes.description: Require that users log out when [Assignment: organization-defined time period of expected inactivity or description of when to log out].

nodes.name: Account Management | Dynamic Privilege Management
nodes.description: Implement [Assignment: organization-defined dynamic privilege management capabilities].

nodes.name: Account Management | Privileged User Accounts
Account Management | Dynamic Account Management
nodes.description: Create, activate, manage, and deactivate [Assignment: organization-defined system accounts] dynamically.

nodes.name: Account Management | Restrictions on Use of Shared and Group Accounts
nodes.description: Only permit the use of shared and group accounts that meet [Assignment: organization-defined conditions for establishing shared and group accounts].

nodes.name: Account Management | Shared and Group Account Credential Change
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into AC-2.

nodes.name: Account Management | Usage Conditions
nodes.description: Enforce [Assignment: organization-defined circumstances and/or usage conditions] for  [Assignment: organization-defined system accounts].

nodes.name: Account Management | Account Monitoring for Atypical Usage
nodes.description:
(a) Monitor system accounts for [Assignment: organization-defined atypical usage]; and
(b) Report atypical usage of system accounts to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles].

nodes.name: Account Management | Disable Accounts for High-risk Individuals
nodes.description: Disable accounts of individuals within [Assignment: organization-defined time period] of discovery of [Assignment: organization-defined significant risks].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement
nodes.description: Enforce approved authorizations for logical access to information and system resources in accordance with applicable access control policies.

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Restricted Access to Privileged Functions
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into AC-6.

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Dual Authorization
nodes.description: Enforce dual authorization for [Assignment: organization-defined privileged commands and/or other organization-defined actions].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Mandatory Access Control
Access Enforcement | Discretionary Access Control
Access Enforcement | Security-relevant Information
nodes.description: Prevent access to [Assignment: organization-defined security-relevant information] except during secure, non-operable system states.

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Protection of User and System Information
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into MP-4, SC-28.

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Role-based Access Control
nodes.description: Enforce a role-based access control policy over defined subjects and objects and control access based upon [Assignment: organization-defined roles and users authorized to assume such roles].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Revocation of Access Authorizations
nodes.description: Enforce the revocation of access authorizations resulting from changes to the security attributes of subjects and objects based on [Assignment: organization-defined rules governing the timing of revocations of access authorizations].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Controlled Release
nodes.description:
Release information outside of the system only if:

(a) The receiving [Assignment: organization-defined system or system component] provides [Assignment: organization-defined controls]; and
(b) [Assignment: organization-defined controls] are used to validate the appropriateness of the information designated for release.

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Audited Override of Access Control Mechanisms
nodes.description: Employ an audited override of automated access control mechanisms under [Assignment: organization-defined conditions] by [Assignment: organization-defined roles].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Restrict Access to Specific Information Types
nodes.description: Restrict access to data repositories containing [Assignment: organization-defined information types].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Assert and Enforce Application Access
Access Enforcement | Attribute-based Access Control
nodes.description: Enforce attribute-based access control policy over defined subjects and objects and control access based upon [Assignment: organization-defined attributes to assume access permissions].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Individual Access
nodes.description: Provide [Assignment: organization-defined mechanisms] to enable individuals to have access to the following elements of their personally identifiable information: [Assignment: organization-defined elements].

nodes.name: Access Enforcement | Discretionary and Mandatory Access Control
nodes.description:
(a) Enforce [Assignment: organization-defined mandatory access control policy] over the set of covered subjects and objects specified in the policy; and
(b) Enforce [Assignment: organization-defined discretionary access control policy] over the set of covered subjects and objects specified in the policy.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement
nodes.description: Enforce approved authorizations for controlling the flow of information within the system and between connected systems based on [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Object Security and Privacy Attributes
nodes.description: Use [Assignment: organization-defined security and privacy attributes] associated with [Assignment: organization-defined information, source, and destination objects] to enforce [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies] as a basis for flow control decisions.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Processing Domains
nodes.description: Use protected processing domains to enforce [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies] as a basis for flow control decisions.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Dynamic Information Flow Control
nodes.description: Enforce [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Flow Control of Encrypted Information
nodes.description: Prevent encrypted information from bypassing [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control mechanisms] by [Selection (one or more): decrypting the information; blocking the flow of the encrypted information; terminating communications sessions attempting to pass encrypted information; [Assignment: organization-defined procedure or method]].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Embedded Data Types
nodes.description: Enforce [Assignment: organization-defined limitations] on embedding data types within other data types.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Metadata
nodes.description: Enforce information flow control based on [Assignment: organization-defined metadata].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | One-way Flow Mechanisms
nodes.description: Enforce one-way information flows through hardware-based flow control mechanisms.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Security and Privacy Policy Filters
nodes.description:
(a) Enforce information flow control using [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy filters] as a basis for flow control decisions for [Assignment: organization-defined information flows]; and
(b) [Selection (one or more): Block; Strip; Modify; Quarantine] data after a filter processing failure in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Human Reviews
nodes.description: Enforce the use of human reviews for [Assignment: organization-defined information flows] under the following conditions: [Assignment: organization-defined conditions].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Enable and Disable Security or Privacy Policy Filters
nodes.description: Provide the capability for privileged administrators to enable and disable [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy filters] under the following conditions: [Assignment: organization-defined conditions].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Configuration of Security or Privacy Policy Filters
nodes.description: Provide the capability for privileged administrators to configure [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy filters] to support different security or privacy policies.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Data Type Identifiers
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, use [Assignment: organization-defined data type identifiers] to validate data essential for information flow decisions.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Decomposition into Policy-relevant Subcomponents
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, decompose information into [Assignment: organization-defined policy-relevant subcomponents] for submission to policy enforcement mechanisms.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Security or Privacy Policy Filter Constraints
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, implement [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy filters] requiring fully enumerated formats that restrict data structure and content.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Detection of Unsanctioned Information
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, examine the information for the presence of [Assignment: organization-defined unsanctioned information] and prohibit the transfer of such information in accordance with the [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Information Transfers on Interconnected Systems
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into AC-4.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Domain Authentication
nodes.description: Uniquely identify and authenticate source and destination points by [Selection (one or more): organization; system; application; service; individual] for information transfer.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Security Attribute Binding
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into AC-16.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Validation of Metadata
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, implement [Assignment: organization-defined security or privacy policy filters] on metadata.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Approved Solutions
nodes.description: Employ [Assignment: organization-defined solutions in approved configurations] to control the flow of [Assignment: organization-defined information] across security domains.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Physical or Logical Separation of Information Flows
nodes.description: Separate information flows logically or physically using [Assignment: organization-defined mechanisms and/or techniques] to accomplish [Assignment: organization-defined required separations by types of information].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Access Only
nodes.description: Provide access from a single device to computing platforms, applications, or data residing in multiple different security domains, while preventing information flow between the different security domains.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Modify Non-releasable Information
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, modify non-releasable information by implementing [Assignment: organization-defined modification action].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Internal Normalized Format
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, parse incoming data into an internal normalized format and regenerate the data to be consistent with its intended specification.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Data Sanitization
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, sanitize data to minimize [Selection (one or more): delivery of malicious content, command and control of malicious code, malicious code augmentation, and steganography encoded data; spillage of sensitive information] in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined policy].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Audit Filtering Actions
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, record and audit content filtering actions and results for the information being filtered.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Redundant/Independent Filtering Mechanisms
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, implement content filtering solutions that provide redundant and independent filtering mechanisms for each data type.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Linear Filter Pipelines
nodes.description: When transferring information between different security domains, implement a linear content filter pipeline that is enforced with discretionary and mandatory access controls.

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Filter Orchestration Engines
nodes.description:
When transferring information between different security domains, employ content filter orchestration engines to ensure that:

(a) Content filtering mechanisms successfully complete execution without errors; and
(b) Content filtering actions occur in the correct order and comply with [Assignment: organization-defined policy].

nodes.name: Information Flow Enforcement | Filter Mechanisms Using Multiple Processes
