nodes.name: Supply Chain Protection
nodes.description:
Withdrawn: incorporated into Supply Chain Risk Management, SR-1Policy and Procedures
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:

1. [Selection (one or more): Organization-level; Mission/business process-level; System-level] supply chain risk management policy that:

(a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
(b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the supply chain risk management policy and the associated supply chain risk management controls;
b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the supply chain risk management policy and procedures; and
c. Review and update the current supply chain risk management:

1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].Supply chain risk management policy and procedures address the controls in the SR family as well as supply chain-related controls in other families that are implemented within systems and organizations. The risk management strategy is an important factor in establishing such policies and procedures. Policies and procedures contribute to security and privacy assurance. Therefore, it is important that security and privacy programs collaborate on the development of supply chain risk management policy and procedures. Security and privacy program policies and procedures at the organization level are preferable, in general, and may obviate the need for mission- or system-specific policies and procedures. The policy can be included as part of the general security and privacy policy or be represented by multiple policies that reflect the complex nature of organizations. Procedures can be established for security and privacy programs, for mission or business processes, and for systems, if needed. Procedures describe how the policies or controls are implemented and can be directed at the individual or role that is the object of the procedure. Procedures can be documented in system security and privacy plans or in one or more separate documents. Events that may precipitate an update to supply chain risk management policy and procedures include assessment or audit findings, security incidents or breaches, or changes in applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines. Simply restating controls does not constitute an organizational policy or procedure.PM-9, PM-30, PS-8, SI-12., SR-2Supply Chain Risk Management Plan
a. Develop a plan for managing supply chain risks associated with the research and development, design, manufacturing, acquisition, delivery, integration, operations and maintenance, and disposal of the following systems, system components or system services: [Assignment: organization-defined systems, system components, or system services];
b. Review and update the supply chain risk management plan [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] or as required, to address threat, organizational or environmental changes; and
c. Protect the supply chain risk management plan from unauthorized disclosure and modification.The dependence on products, systems, and services from external providers, as well as the nature of the relationships with those providers, present an increasing level of risk to an organization. Threat actions that may increase security or privacy risks include unauthorized production, the insertion or use of counterfeits, tampering, theft, insertion of malicious software and hardware, and poor manufacturing and development practices in the supply chain. Supply chain risks can be endemic or systemic within a system element or component, a system, an organization, a sector, or the Nation. Managing supply chain risk is a complex, multifaceted undertaking that requires a coordinated effort across an organization to build trust relationships and communicate with internal and external stakeholders. Supply chain risk management (SCRM) activities include identifying and assessing risks, determining appropriate risk response actions, developing SCRM plans to document response actions, and monitoring performance against plans. The SCRM plan (at the system-level) is implementation specific, providing policy implementation, requirements, constraints and implications. It can either be stand-alone, or incorporated into system security and privacy plans. The SCRM plan addresses managing, implementation, and monitoring of SCRM controls and the development/sustainment of systems across the SDLC to support mission and business functions.
Because supply chains can differ significantly across and within organizations, SCRM plans are tailored to the individual program, organizational, and operational contexts. Tailored SCRM plans provide the basis for determining whether a technology, service, system component, or system is fit for purpose, and as such, the controls need to be tailored accordingly. Tailored SCRM plans help organizations focus their resources on the most critical mission and business functions based on mission and business requirements and their risk environment. Supply chain risk management plans include an expression of the supply chain risk tolerance for the organization, acceptable supply chain risk mitigation strategies or controls, a process for consistently evaluating and monitoring supply chain risk, approaches for implementing and communicating the plan, a description of and justification for supply chain risk mitigation measures taken, and associated roles and responsibilities. Finally, supply chain risk management plans address requirements for developing trustworthy, secure, privacy-protective, and resilient system components and systems, including the application of the security design principles implemented as part of life cycle-based systems security engineering processes (see SA-8).CA-2, CP-4, IR-4, MA-2, MA-6, PE-16, PL-2, PM-9, PM-30, RA-3, RA-7, SA-8, SI-4., SR-3Supply Chain Controls and Processes
a. Establish a process or processes to identify and address weaknesses or deficiencies in the supply chain elements and processes of [Assignment: organization-defined system or system component] in coordination with [Assignment: organization-defined supply chain personnel];
b. Employ the following controls to protect against supply chain risks to the system, system component, or system service and to limit the harm or consequences from supply chain-related events: [Assignment: organization-defined supply chain controls]; and
c. Document the selected and implemented supply chain processes and controls in [Selection: security and privacy plans; supply chain risk management plan; [Assignment: organization-defined document]].Supply chain elements include organizations, entities, or tools employed for the research and development, design, manufacturing, acquisition, delivery, integration, operations and maintenance, and disposal of systems and system components. Supply chain processes include hardware, software, and firmware development processes; shipping and handling procedures; personnel security and physical security programs; configuration management tools, techniques, and measures to maintain provenance; or other programs, processes, or procedures associated with the development, acquisition, maintenance and disposal of systems and system components. Supply chain elements and processes may be provided by organizations, system integrators, or external providers. Weaknesses or deficiencies in supply chain elements or processes represent potential vulnerabilities that can be exploited by adversaries to cause harm to the organization and affect its ability to carry out its core missions or business functions. Supply chain personnel are individuals with roles and responsibilities in the supply chain.CA-2, MA-2, MA-6, PE-3, PE-16, PL-8, PM-30, SA-2, SA-3, SA-4, SA-5, SA-8, SA-9, SA-10, SA-15, SC-7, SC-29, SC-30, SC-38, SI-7, SR-6, SR-9, SR-11., SR-4ProvenanceDocument, monitor, and maintain valid provenance of the following systems, system components, and associated data: [Assignment: organization-defined systems, system components, and associated data].Every system and system component has a point of origin and may be changed throughout its existence. Provenance is the chronology of the origin, development, ownership, location, and changes to a system or system component and associated data. It may also include personnel and processes used to interact with or make modifications to the system, component, or associated data. Organizations consider developing procedures (see SR-1) for allocating responsibilities for the creation, maintenance, and monitoring of provenance for systems and system components; transferring provenance documentation and responsibility between organizations; and preventing and monitoring for unauthorized changes to the provenance records. Organizations have methods to document, monitor, and maintain valid provenance baselines for systems, system components, and related data. These actions help track, assess, and document any changes to the provenance, including changes in supply chain elements or configuration, and help ensure non-repudiation of provenance information and the provenance change records. Provenance considerations are addressed throughout the system development life cycle and incorporated into contracts and other arrangements, as appropriate.CM-8, MA-2, MA-6, RA-9, SA-3, SA-8, SI-4., SR-5Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and MethodsEmploy the following acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods to protect against, identify, and mitigate supply chain risks: [Assignment: organization-defined acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods].The use of the acquisition process provides an important vehicle to protect the supply chain. There are many useful tools and techniques available, including obscuring the end use of a system or system component, using blind or filtered buys, requiring tamper-evident packaging, or using trusted or controlled distribution. The results from a supply chain risk assessment can guide and inform the strategies, tools, and methods that are most applicable to the situation. Tools and techniques may provide protections against unauthorized production, theft, tampering, insertion of counterfeits, insertion of malicious software or backdoors, and poor development practices throughout the system development life cycle. Organizations also consider providing incentives for suppliers who implement controls, promote transparency into their processes and security and privacy practices, provide contract language that addresses the prohibition of tainted or counterfeit components, and restrict purchases from untrustworthy suppliers. Organizations consider providing training, education, and awareness programs for personnel regarding supply chain risk, available mitigation strategies, and when the programs should be employed. Methods for reviewing and protecting development plans, documentation, and evidence are commensurate with the security and privacy requirements of the organization. Contracts may specify documentation protection requirements.AT-3, SA-2, SA-3, SA-4, SA-5, SA-8, SA-9, SA-10, SA-15, SR-6, SR-9, SR-10, SR-11., SR-6Supplier Assessments and ReviewsAssess and review the supply chain-related risks associated with suppliers or contractors and the system, system component, or system service they provide [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].An assessment and review of supplier risk includes security and supply chain risk management processes, foreign ownership, control or influence (FOCI), and the ability of the supplier to effectively assess subordinate second-tier and third-tier suppliers and contractors. The reviews may be conducted by the organization or by an independent third party. The reviews consider documented processes, documented controls, all-source intelligence, and publicly available information related to the supplier or contractor. Organizations can use open-source information to monitor for indications of stolen information, poor development and quality control practices, information spillage, or counterfeits. In some cases, it may be appropriate or required to share assessment and review results with other organizations in accordance with any applicable rules, policies, or inter-organizational agreements or contracts.SR-3, SR-5., SR-7Supply Chain Operations SecurityEmploy the following Operations Security (OPSEC) controls to protect supply chain-related information for the system, system component, or system service: [Assignment: organization-defined Operations Security (OPSEC) controls].Supply chain OPSEC expands the scope of OPSEC to include suppliers and potential suppliers. OPSEC is a process that includes identifying critical information, analyzing friendly actions related to operations and other activities to identify actions that can be observed by potential adversaries, determining indicators that potential adversaries might obtain that could be interpreted or pieced together to derive information in sufficient time to cause harm to organizations, implementing safeguards or countermeasures to eliminate or reduce exploitable vulnerabilities and risk to an acceptable level, and considering how aggregated information may expose users or specific uses of the supply chain. Supply chain information includes user identities; uses for systems, system components, and system services; supplier identities; security and privacy requirements; system and component configurations; supplier processes; design specifications; and testing and evaluation results. Supply chain OPSEC may require organizations to withhold mission or business information from suppliers and may include the use of intermediaries to hide the end use or users of systems, system components, or system services.SC-38., SR-8Notification AgreementsEstablish agreements and procedures with entities involved in the supply chain for the system, system component, or system service for the [Selection (one or more): notification of supply chain compromises; results of assessments or audits; [Assignment: organization-defined information]].The establishment of agreements and procedures facilitates communications among supply chain entities. Early notification of compromises and potential compromises in the supply chain that can potentially adversely affect or have adversely affected organizational systems or system components is essential for organizations to effectively respond to such incidents. The results of assessments or audits may include open-source information that contributed to a decision or result and could be used to help the supply chain entity resolve a concern or improve its processes.IR-4, IR-6, IR-8., SR-9Tamper Resistance and DetectionImplement a tamper protection program for the system, system component, or system service.Anti-tamper technologies, tools, and techniques provide a level of protection for systems, system components, and services against many threats, including reverse engineering, modification, and substitution. Strong identification combined with tamper resistance and/or tamper detection is essential to protecting systems and components during distribution and when in use.PE-3, PM-30, SA-15, SI-4, SI-7, SR-3, SR-4, SR-5, SR-10, SR-11., SR-10Inspection of Systems or ComponentsInspect the following systems or system components [Selection (one or more): at random; at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency], upon [Assignment: organization-defined indications of need for inspection]] to detect tampering: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].The inspection of systems or systems components for tamper resistance and detection addresses physical and logical tampering and is applied to systems and system components removed from organization-controlled areas. Indications of a need for inspection include changes in packaging, specifications, factory location, or entity in which the part is purchased, and when individuals return from travel to high-risk locations.AT-3, PM-30, SI-4, SI-7, SR-3, SR-4, SR-5, SR-9, SR-11., SR-11Component Authenticity
a. Develop and implement anti-counterfeit policy and procedures that include the means to detect and prevent counterfeit components from entering the system; and
b. Report counterfeit system components to [Selection (one or more): source of counterfeit component; [Assignment: organization-defined external reporting organizations]; [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]].Sources of counterfeit components include manufacturers, developers, vendors, and contractors. Anti-counterfeiting policies and procedures support tamper resistance and provide a level of protection against the introduction of malicious code. External reporting organizations include CISA.PE-3, SA-4, SI-7, SR-9, SR-10., SR-12Component DisposalDispose of [Assignment: organization-defined data, documentation, tools, or system components] using the following techniques and methods: [Assignment: organization-defined techniques and methods].Data, documentation, tools, or system components can be disposed of at any time during the system development life cycle (not only in the disposal or retirement phase of the life cycle). For example, disposal can occur during research and development, design, prototyping, or operations/maintenance and include methods such as disk cleaning, removal of cryptographic keys, partial reuse of components. Opportunities for compromise during disposal affect physical and logical data, including system documentation in paper-based or digital files; shipping and delivery documentation; memory sticks with software code; or complete routers or servers that include permanent media, which contain sensitive or proprietary information. Additionally, proper disposal of system components helps to prevent such components from entering the gray market.MP-6..

nodes.description:
Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to:

nodes.name: Development Process, Standards, and Tools | Archive System or Component
nodes.description: Require the developer of the system or system component to archive the system or component to be released or delivered together with the corresponding evidence supporting the final security and privacy review.

nodes.name: Development Process, Standards, and Tools | Minimize Personally Identifiable Information
nodes.description: Require the developer of the system or system component to minimize the use of personally identifiable information in development and test environments.

nodes.name: Developer-provided Training
nodes.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to provide the following training on the correct use and operation of the implemented security and privacy functions, controls, and/or mechanisms: [Assignment: organization-defined training].

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design
nodes.description:
Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to produce a design specification and security and privacy architecture that:

a. Is consistent with the organization���s security and privacy architecture that is an integral part the organization���s enterprise architecture;
b. Accurately and completely describes the required security and privacy functionality, and the allocation of controls among physical and logical components; and
c. Expresses how individual security and privacy functions, mechanisms, and services work together to provide required security and privacy capabilities and a unified approach to protection.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Formal Policy Model
nodes.description:
Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to:

(a) Produce, as an integral part of the development process, a formal policy model describing the [Assignment: organization-defined elements of organizational security and privacy policy] to be enforced; and
(b) Prove that the formal policy model is internally consistent and sufficient to enforce the defined elements of the organizational security and privacy policy when implemented.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Security-relevant Components
nodes.description:
Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to:

(a) Define security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware; and
(b) Provide a rationale that the definition for security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware is complete.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Formal Correspondence
Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Informal Correspondence
Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Conceptually Simple Design
nodes.description:
Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to:

(a) Design and structure the security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware to use a complete, conceptually simple protection mechanism with precisely defined semantics; and
(b) Internally structure the security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware with specific regard for this mechanism.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Structure for Testing
nodes.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to structure security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware to facilitate testing.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Structure for Least Privilege
nodes.description: Require the developer of the system, system component, or system service to structure security-relevant hardware, software, and firmware to facilitate controlling access with least privilege.

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Orchestration
nodes.description: Design [Assignment: organization-defined critical systems or system components] with coordinated behavior to implement the following capabilities: [Assignment: organization-defined capabilities, by system or component].

nodes.name: Developer Security and Privacy Architecture and Design | Design Diversity
nodes.description: Use different designs for [Assignment: organization-defined critical systems or system components] to satisfy a common set of requirements or to provide equivalent functionality.

nodes.name: Specialization
nodes.description: Employ [Selection (one or more): design; modification; augmentation; reconfiguration] on [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components] supporting mission essential services or functions to increase the trustworthiness in those systems or components.

nodes.name: Policy and Procedures
nodes.description:
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:

1. [Selection (one or more): Organization-level; Mission/business process-level; System-level] system and communications protection policy that:

(a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
(b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and communications protection policy and the associated system and communications protection controls;
b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the system and communications protection policy and procedures; and
c. Review and update the current system and communications protection:

1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].

nodes.name: Separation of System and User Functionality
nodes.description: Separate user functionality, including user interface services, from system management functionality.

nodes.name: Separation of System and User Functionality | Interfaces for Non-privileged Users
nodes.description: Prevent the presentation of system management functionality at interfaces to non-privileged users.

nodes.name: Separation of System and User Functionality | Disassociability
nodes.description: Store state information from applications and software separately.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation
nodes.description: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation | Hardware Separation
nodes.description: Employ hardware separation mechanisms to implement security function isolation.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation | Access and Flow Control Functions
nodes.description: Isolate security functions enforcing access and information flow control from nonsecurity functions and from other security functions.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation | Minimize Nonsecurity Functionality
nodes.description: Minimize the number of nonsecurity functions included within the isolation boundary containing security functions.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation | Module Coupling and Cohesiveness
nodes.description: Implement security functions as largely independent modules that maximize internal cohesiveness within modules and minimize coupling between modules.

nodes.name: Security Function Isolation | Layered Structures
nodes.description: Implement security functions as a layered structure minimizing interactions between layers of the design and avoiding any dependence by lower layers on the functionality or correctness of higher layers.

nodes.name: Information in Shared System Resources
nodes.description: Prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.

nodes.name: Information in Shared System Resources | Multilevel or Periods Processing
nodes.description: Prevent unauthorized information transfer via shared resources in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined procedures] when system processing explicitly switches between different information classification levels or security categories.

b. Employ the following controls to achieve the denial-of-service objective: [Assignment: organization-defined controls by type of denial-of-service event].

nodes.name: Denial-of-service Protection | Capacity, Bandwidth, and Redundancy
nodes.description: Manage capacity, bandwidth, or other redundancy to limit the effects of information flooding denial-of-service attacks.

nodes.name: Denial-of-service Protection | Detection and Monitoring
nodes.description:
(a) Employ the following monitoring tools to detect indicators of denial-of-service attacks against, or launched from, the system: [Assignment: organization-defined monitoring tools]; and
(b) Monitor the following system resources to determine if sufficient resources exist to prevent effective denial-of-service attacks: [Assignment: organization-defined system resources].

nodes.name: Resource Availability
nodes.description: Protect the availability of resources by allocating [Assignment: organization-defined resources] by [Selection (one or more): priority; quota; [Assignment: organization-defined controls]].

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Prevent Exfiltration

(a) Prevent the exfiltration of information; and
(b) Conduct exfiltration tests [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Restrict Incoming Communications Traffic

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Host-based Protection
nodes.description: Implement [Assignment: organization-defined host-based boundary protection mechanisms] at [Assignment: organization-defined system components].

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Protect Against Unauthorized Physical Connections

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Networked Privileged Accesses

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Prevent Discovery of System Components

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Automated Enforcement of Protocol Formats

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Fail Secure

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Block Communication from Non-organizationally Configured Hosts

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Dynamic Isolation and Segregation
nodes.description: Provide the capability to dynamically isolate [Assignment: organization-defined system components] from other system components.

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Isolation of System Components
nodes.description: Employ boundary protection mechanisms to isolate [Assignment: organization-defined system components] supporting [Assignment: organization-defined missions and/or business functions].

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Disable Sender Feedback on Protocol Validation Failure

Boundary Protection | Unclassified National Security System Connections

nodes.name: Boundary Protection | Classified National Security System Connections

nodes.name: Transmission Confidentiality and Integrity

nodes.description: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to [Selection (one or more): prevent unauthorized disclosure of information; detect changes to information] during transmission.

nodes.description: Maintain the [Selection (one or more): confidentiality; integrity] of information during preparation for transmission and during reception.

nodes.name: Transmission Confidentiality and Integrity | Protected Distribution System

a. Employ integrity verification tools to detect unauthorized changes to the following software, firmware, and information: [Assignment: organization-defined software, firmware, and information]; and

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Integrity Checks
nodes.description:
Perform an integrity check of [Assignment: organization-defined software, firmware, and information]
                  [Selection (one or more): at startup; at [Assignment: organization-defined transitional states or security-relevant events]; [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Automated Notifications of Integrity Violations
nodes.description: Employ automated tools that provide notification to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles] upon discovering discrepancies during integrity verification.

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Centrally Managed Integrity Tools
nodes.description: Employ centrally managed integrity verification tools.

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Tamper-evident Packaging
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into SR-9.

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Automated Response to Integrity Violations
nodes.description: Automatically [Selection (one or more): shut the system down; restart the system; implement [Assignment: organization-defined controls]] when integrity violations are discovered.

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Cryptographic Protection
nodes.description: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to detect unauthorized changes to software, firmware, and information.

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Integration of Detection and Response
nodes.description: Incorporate the detection of the following unauthorized changes into the organizational incident response capability: [Assignment: organization-defined security-relevant changes to the system].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Auditing Capability for Significant Events
nodes.description: Upon detection of a potential integrity violation, provide the capability to audit the event and initiate the following actions: [Selection (one or more): generate an audit record; alert current user; alert [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]; [Assignment: organization-defined other actions]].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Verify Boot Process
nodes.description: Verify the integrity of the boot process of the following system components: [Assignment: organization-defined system components].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Protection of Boot Firmware
nodes.description: Implement the following mechanisms to protect the integrity of boot firmware in [Assignment: organization-defined system components]: [Assignment: organization-defined mechanisms].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Confined Environments with Limited Privileges
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into CM-7(6).

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Integrity Verification
nodes.description: Require that the integrity of the following user-installed software be verified prior to execution: [Assignment: organization-defined user-installed software].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Code Execution in Protected Environments
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into CM-7(7).

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Binary or Machine Executable Code
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into CM-7(8).

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Code Authentication
nodes.description: Implement cryptographic mechanisms to authenticate the following software or firmware components prior to installation: [Assignment: organization-defined software or firmware components].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Time Limit on Process Execution Without Supervision
nodes.description: Prohibit processes from executing without supervision for more than [Assignment: organization-defined time period].

nodes.name: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity | Runtime Application Self-protection
nodes.description: Implement [Assignment: organization-defined controls] for application self-protection at runtime.

nodes.name: Spam Protection
nodes.description:
a. Employ spam protection mechanisms at system entry and exit points to detect and act on unsolicited messages; and
b. Update spam protection mechanisms when new releases are available in accordance with organizational configuration management policy and procedures.

nodes.name: Spam Protection | Central Management
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into PL-9.

nodes.name: Spam Protection | Automatic Updates
nodes.description: Automatically update spam protection mechanisms [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

nodes.name: Spam Protection | Continuous Learning Capability
nodes.description: Implement spam protection mechanisms with a learning capability to more effectively identify legitimate communications traffic.

nodes.name: Information Input Restrictions
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, AC-6.

nodes.name: Information Input Validation
nodes.description: Check the validity of the following information inputs: [Assignment: organization-defined information inputs to the system].

nodes.name: Information Input Validation | Manual Override Capability
Information Input Validation | Review and Resolve Errors
nodes.description: Review and resolve input validation errors within [Assignment: organization-defined time period].

nodes.name: Information Input Validation | Predictable Behavior
nodes.description: Verify that the system behaves in a predictable and documented manner when invalid inputs are received.

nodes.name: Information Input Validation | Timing Interactions
nodes.description: Account for timing interactions among system components in determining appropriate responses for invalid inputs.

nodes.name: Information Input Validation | Restrict Inputs to Trusted Sources and Approved Formats
nodes.description: Restrict the use of information inputs to [Assignment: organization-defined trusted sources] and/or [Assignment: organization-defined formats].

nodes.name: Information Input Validation | Injection Prevention
nodes.description: Prevent untrusted data injections.

nodes.name: Error Handling
nodes.description:
a. Generate error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing information that could be exploited; and
b. Reveal error messages only to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles].

nodes.name: Information Management and Retention
nodes.description: Manage and retain information within the system and information output from the system in accordance with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, guidelines and operational requirements.

nodes.name: Information Management and Retention | Limit Personally Identifiable Information Elements
nodes.description: Limit personally identifiable information being processed in the information life cycle to the following elements of personally identifiable information: [Assignment: organization-defined elements of personally identifiable information].

nodes.name: Information Management and Retention | Minimize Personally Identifiable Information in Testing, Training, and Research
nodes.description: Use the following techniques to minimize the use of personally identifiable information for research, testing, or training: [Assignment: organization-defined techniques].

nodes.name: Information Management and Retention | Information Disposal
nodes.description: Use the following techniques to dispose of, destroy, or erase information following the retention period: [Assignment: organization-defined techniques].

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention
nodes.description:
a. Determine mean time to failure (MTTF) for the following system components in specific environments of operation: [Assignment: organization-defined system components]; and
b. Provide substitute system components and a means to exchange active and standby components in accordance with the following criteria: [Assignment: organization-defined MTTF substitution criteria].

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention | Transferring Component Responsibilities
nodes.description: Take system components out of service by transferring component responsibilities to substitute components no later than [Assignment: organization-defined fraction or percentage] of mean time to failure.

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention | Time Limit on Process Execution Without Supervision
nodes.description: Withdrawn: incorporated into SI-7(16).

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention | Manual Transfer Between Components
nodes.description: Manually initiate transfers between active and standby system components when the use of the active component reaches [Assignment: organization-defined percentage] of the mean time to failure.

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention | Standby Component Installation and Notification
nodes.description:
If system component failures are detected:

(a) Ensure that the standby components are successfully and transparently installed within [Assignment: organization-defined time period]; and
(b) [Selection (one or more): Activate [Assignment: organization-defined alarm]; Automatically shut down the system; [Assignment: organization-defined action]].

nodes.name: Predictable Failure Prevention | Failover Capability
nodes.description:
Provide [Selection: real-time; near real-time]
                  [Assignment: organization-defined failover capability] for the system.

nodes.name: Non-persistence
nodes.description: Implement non-persistent [Assignment: organization-defined system components and services] that are initiated in a known state and terminated [Selection (one or more): upon end of session of use; periodically at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]].

nodes.name: Non-persistence | Refresh from Trusted Sources
nodes.description: Obtain software and data employed during system component and service refreshes from the following trusted sources: [Assignment: organization-defined trusted sources].

nodes.name: Non-persistence | Non-persistent Information
nodes.description:
(a) [Selection: Refresh [Assignment: organization-defined information][Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; Generate [Assignment: organization-defined information] on demand]; and
(b) Delete information when no longer needed.

nodes.name: Non-persistence | Non-persistent Connectivity
nodes.description: Establish connections to the system on demand and terminate connections after [Selection: completion of a request; a period of non-use].

nodes.name: Information Output Filtering
nodes.description: Validate information output from the following software programs and/or applications to ensure that the information is consistent with the expected content: [Assignment: organization-defined software programs and/or applications].

nodes.name: Memory Protection
nodes.description: Implement the following controls to protect the system memory from unauthorized code execution: [Assignment: organization-defined controls].

nodes.name: Fail-safe Procedures
nodes.description: Implement the indicated fail-safe procedures when the indicated failures occur: [Assignment: organization-defined list of failure conditions and associated fail-safe procedures].

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations
nodes.description:
a. Check the accuracy, relevance, timeliness, and completeness of personally identifiable information across the information life cycle [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and
b. Correct or delete inaccurate or outdated personally identifiable information.

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations | Automation Support
nodes.description: Correct or delete personally identifiable information that is inaccurate or outdated, incorrectly determined regarding impact, or incorrectly de-identified using [Assignment: organization-defined automated mechanisms].

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations | Data Tags
nodes.description: Employ data tags to automate the correction or deletion of personally identifiable information across the information life cycle within organizational systems.

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations | Collection
nodes.description: Collect personally identifiable information directly from the individual.

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations | Individual Requests
nodes.description: Correct or delete personally identifiable information upon request by individuals or their designated representatives.

nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations | Notice of Correction or Deletion
nodes.description: Notify [Assignment: organization-defined recipients of personally identifiable information] and individuals that the personally identifiable information has been corrected or deleted.

nodes.name: De-identification
nodes.description:
a. Remove the following elements of personally identifiable information from datasets: [Assignment: organization-defined elements of personally identifiable information]; and
b. Evaluate [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] for effectiveness of de-identification.

nodes.name: De-identification | Collection
nodes.description: De-identify the dataset upon collection by not collecting personally identifiable information.

nodes.name: De-identification | Archiving
nodes.description: Prohibit archiving of personally identifiable information elements if those elements in a dataset will not be needed after the dataset is archived.

nodes.name: De-identification | Release
nodes.description: Remove personally identifiable information elements from a dataset prior to its release if those elements in the dataset do not need to be part of the data release.

nodes.name: De-identification | Removal, Masking, Encryption, Hashing, or Replacement of Direct Identifiers
nodes.description: Remove, mask, encrypt, hash, or replace direct identifiers in a dataset.

nodes.name: De-identification | Statistical Disclosure Control
nodes.description: Manipulate numerical data, contingency tables, and statistical findings so that no individual or organization is identifiable in the results of the analysis.

nodes.name: De-identification | Differential Privacy
nodes.description: Prevent disclosure of personally identifiable information by adding non-deterministic noise to the results of mathematical operations before the results are reported.

nodes.name: De-identification | Validated Algorithms and Software
nodes.description: Perform de-identification using validated algorithms and software that is validated to implement the algorithms.

nodes.name: De-identification | Motivated Intruder
nodes.description: Perform a motivated intruder test on the de-identified dataset to determine if the identified data remains or if the de-identified data can be re-identified.

nodes.name: Tainting
nodes.description: Embed data or capabilities in the following systems or system components to determine if organizational data has been exfiltrated or improperly removed from the organization: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

nodes.name: Information Refresh
nodes.description: Refresh [Assignment: organization-defined information] at [Assignment: organization-defined frequencies] or generate the information on demand and delete the information when no longer needed.

nodes.name: Information Diversity
nodes.description:
a. Identify the following alternative sources of information for [Assignment: organization-defined essential functions and services]: [Assignment: organization-defined alternative information sources]; and
b. Use an alternative information source for the execution of essential functions or services on [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components] when the primary source of information is corrupted or unavailable.

nodes.name: Information Fragmentation
nodes.description:
Based on [Assignment: organization-defined circumstances]:

a. Fragment the following information: [Assignment: organization-defined information]; and
b. Distribute the fragmented information across the following systems or system components: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

nodes.name: Policy and Procedures
nodes.description:
a. Develop, document, and disseminate to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]:

1. [Selection (one or more): Organization-level; Mission/business process-level; System-level] supply chain risk management policy that:

(a) Addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and
(b) Is consistent with applicable laws, executive orders, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines; and
2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the supply chain risk management policy and the associated supply chain risk management controls;
b. Designate an [Assignment: organization-defined official] to manage the development, documentation, and dissemination of the supply chain risk management policy and procedures; and
c. Review and update the current supply chain risk management:

1. Policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events]; and
2. Procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and following [Assignment: organization-defined events].

nodes.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Plan
Supply Chain Risk Management Plan | Establish Scrm Team
nodes.description: Establish a supply chain risk management team consisting of [Assignment: organization-defined personnel, roles, and responsibilities] to lead and support the following SCRM activities: [Assignment: organization-defined supply chain risk management activities].

nodes.name: Supply Chain Controls and Processes
Supply Chain Controls and Processes | Diverse Supply Base
nodes.description: Employ a diverse set of sources for the following system components and services:  [Assignment: organization-defined system components and services].

nodes.name: Supply Chain Controls and Processes | Limitation of Harm
nodes.description: Employ the following controls to limit harm from potential adversaries identifying and targeting the organizational supply chain: [Assignment: organization-defined controls].

nodes.name: Supply Chain Controls and Processes | Sub-tier Flow Down
nodes.description: Ensure that the controls included in the contracts of prime contractors are also included in the contracts of subcontractors.

nodes.name: Provenance
nodes.description: Document, monitor, and maintain valid provenance of the following systems, system components, and associated data: [Assignment: organization-defined systems, system components, and associated data].

nodes.name: Provenance | Identity
nodes.description: Establish and maintain unique identification of the following supply chain elements, processes, and personnel associated with the identified system and critical system components: [Assignment: organization-defined supply chain elements, processes, and personnel associated with organization-defined systems and critical system components].

nodes.name: Provenance | Track and Trace
nodes.description: Establish and maintain unique identification of the following systems and critical system components for tracking through the supply chain: [Assignment: organization-defined systems and critical system components].

nodes.name: Provenance | Validate as Genuine and Not Altered
nodes.description: Employ the following controls to validate that the system or system component received is genuine and has not been altered: [Assignment: organization-defined controls].

nodes.name: Provenance | Supply Chain Integrity ��� Pedigree
nodes.description: Employ [Assignment: organization-defined controls] and conduct [Assignment: organization-defined analysis] to ensure the integrity of the system and system components by validating the internal composition and provenance of critical or mission-essential technologies, products, and services.

nodes.name: Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and Methods
nodes.description: Employ the following acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods to protect against, identify, and mitigate supply chain risks: [Assignment: organization-defined acquisition strategies, contract tools, and procurement methods].

nodes.name: Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and Methods | Adequate Supply
nodes.description: Employ the following controls to ensure an adequate supply of [Assignment: organization-defined critical system components]: [Assignment: organization-defined controls].

nodes.name: Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and Methods | Assessments Prior to Selection, Acceptance, Modification, or Update
nodes.description: Assess the system, system component, or system service prior to selection, acceptance, modification, or update.

nodes.name: Supplier Assessments and Reviews
nodes.description: Assess and review the supply chain-related risks associated with suppliers or contractors and the system, system component, or system service they provide [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

nodes.name: Supplier Assessments and Reviews | Testing and Analysis
nodes.description: Employ [Selection (one or more): organizational analysis; independent third-party analysis; organizational testing; independent third-party testing] of the following supply chain elements, processes, and actors associated with the system, system component, or system service: [Assignment: organization-defined supply chain elements, processes, and actors].

nodes.name: Supply Chain Operations Security
nodes.description: Employ the following Operations Security (OPSEC) controls to protect supply chain-related information for the system, system component, or system service: [Assignment: organization-defined Operations Security (OPSEC) controls].

nodes.name: Notification Agreements
nodes.description: Establish agreements and procedures with entities involved in the supply chain for the system, system component, or system service for the [Selection (one or more): notification of supply chain compromises; results of assessments or audits; [Assignment: organization-defined information]].

nodes.name: Tamper Resistance and Detection
nodes.description: Implement a tamper protection program for the system, system component, or system service.

nodes.name: Tamper Resistance and Detection | Multiple Stages of System Development Life Cycle
nodes.description: Employ anti-tamper technologies, tools, and techniques throughout the system development life cycle.

nodes.name: Inspection of Systems or Components
nodes.description: Inspect the following systems or system components [Selection (one or more): at random; at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency], upon [Assignment: organization-defined indications of need for inspection]] to detect tampering: [Assignment: organization-defined systems or system components].

nodes.name: Component Authenticity
nodes.description:
a. Develop and implement anti-counterfeit policy and procedures that include the means to detect and prevent counterfeit components from entering the system; and
b. Report counterfeit system components to [Selection (one or more): source of counterfeit component; [Assignment: organization-defined external reporting organizations]; [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]].

nodes.name: Component Authenticity | Anti-counterfeit Training
nodes.description: Train [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles] to detect counterfeit system components (including hardware, software, and firmware).

nodes.name: Component Authenticity | Configuration Control for Component Service and Repair
nodes.description: Maintain configuration control over the following system components awaiting service or repair and serviced or repaired components awaiting return to service: [Assignment: organization-defined system components].

nodes.name: Component Authenticity | Anti-counterfeit Scanning
nodes.description: Scan for counterfeit system components [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

nodes.name: Component Disposal
nodes.description: Dispose of [Assignment: organization-defined data, documentation, tools, or system components] using the following techniques and methods: [Assignment: organization-defined techniques and methods].
Senior executive responsible for authorizing system operation
Individual responsible for system development, procurement, and maintenance
Individual responsible for system security throughout system lifecycle
Individual responsible for conducting security control assessments
Individual responsible for implementing common controls

nodes.name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act
nodes.description: Federal law that requires financial institutions to explain their information-sharing practices to their customers and to safeguard sensitive data. It includes the Financial Privacy Rule, Safeguards Rule, and pretexting provisions.

nodes.name: Financial Privacy Rule
nodes.description: Governs disclosure of nonpublic personal information

nodes.name: Safeguards Rule
nodes.description: Requires comprehensive information security program

nodes.heading: Content of privacy notices
nodes.text: The privacy notice must include: categories of NPI collected, categories of NPI disclosed, categories of affiliates and nonaffiliated third parties to whom NPI is disclosed

nodes.heading: Limits on disclosure to nonaffiliated third parties
nodes.text: You may not disclose any NPI to a nonaffiliated third party unless you have provided notice and reasonable opportunity to opt out.

nodes.heading: Standards for Safeguarding
nodes.text: You shall develop, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program

nodes.heading: Elements of Information Security Program
nodes.text: Designate a qualified individual, conduct risk assessments, design safeguards, monitor effectiveness
Provide clear and conspicuous notice to customers that accurately reflects privacy policies and practices.
Provide reasonable opportunity and means for consumers to opt out of NPI sharing with nonaffiliated third parties.
Conduct a written risk assessment identifying internal and external risks to NPI.
Implement safeguards to control risks identified in assessment (encryption, MFA, etc.).
Oversee service providers to ensure they maintain appropriate safeguards.

nodes.name: Financial Institution
nodes.description: Institution significantly engaged in financial activities (banks, insurers, lenders)

nodes.name: Consumer
nodes.description: Individual who obtains a financial product/service for personal/family use

nodes.name: Customer
nodes.description: Consumer who has a continuing relationship with the financial institution (e.g., loan, account)

nodes.name: Affiliate
nodes.description: Entity that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with the financial institution

nodes.name: Nonaffiliated Third Party
nodes.description: Any entity that is not an affiliate of the financial institution

nodes.name: Service Provider
nodes.description: Entity that maintains or processes customer information for the institution

nodes.examples: Account balance, payment history, credit score, fact of relationship
nodes.name: Nonpublic Personal Information
nodes.description: Personally identifiable financial information that is not publicly available

nodes.examples: Application form data, transaction records, credit reports
nodes.name: Personally Identifiable Financial Information
nodes.description: Information about consumer obtained in connection with providing a financial product or service

nodes.examples: Telephone directory listings, mortgage records from county recorder
nodes.name: Publicly Available Information
nodes.description: Information lawfully made available from government records, media, or required disclosures

nodes.name: Establish Customer Relationship
nodes.deadline: Not later than when relationship is established

nodes.name: Opt-Out Request
nodes.deadline: Process within reasonable time after request

nodes.name: Security Incident
nodes.deadline: Notify qualifying customers without unreasonable delay

nodes.name: Annual Notice Due
nodes.deadline: At least once in any period of 12 consecutive months

nodes.name: Written Risk Assessment
nodes.description: Periodic written risk assessment identifying internal and external risks to NPI

nodes.name: Encryption of NPI at Rest and Transit
nodes.description: Encryption of customer information held or transmitted by the institution

nodes.name: Multi-Factor Authentication
nodes.description: Multi-factor authentication for access to systems containing NPI

nodes.name: Incident Response Plan
nodes.description: Written incident response plan to respond to security events

nodes.name: Service Provider Assessment
nodes.description: Due diligence and oversight of service providers handling NPI

nodes.name: Access Controls
nodes.description: Role-based access controls limiting access to NPI

nodes.name: Continuous Monitoring
nodes.description: Continuous monitoring and testing of security controls
Civil penalties for violations of GLBA
Cease and desist orders to stop violations
Administrative actions by banking regulators
Removal of officers or prohibition from industry participation

nodes.name: HIPAA
nodes.description: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) is a US regulation that sets standards for protecting sensitive patient health information.
nodes.abbreviation: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to prevent, detect, contain, and correct security violations
nodes.title: Security Management Process

nodes.text: Conduct an accurate and thorough assessment of the potential risks and vulnerabilities to the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of ePHI
nodes.title: Risk Analysis

nodes.text: Implement security measures sufficient to reduce risks and vulnerabilities to a reasonable and appropriate level
nodes.title: Risk Management

nodes.text: Apply appropriate sanctions against workforce members who fail to comply with security policies and procedures
nodes.title: Sanction Policy

nodes.text: Implement procedures to regularly review records of information system activity, such as audit logs, access reports, and security incident tracking reports
nodes.title: Information System Activity Review

nodes.text: Identify the security official who is responsible for the development and implementation of security policies and procedures
nodes.title: Assigned Security Responsibility

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to ensure that all workforce members have appropriate access to ePHI
nodes.title: Workforce Security

nodes.text: Implement procedures for authorization and/or supervision of workforce members who work with ePHI
nodes.title: Authorization and/or Supervision

nodes.text: Implement procedures to determine that workforce member access to ePHI is appropriate
nodes.title: Workforce Clearance Procedure

nodes.text: Implement procedures for terminating access to ePHI when employment or other arrangements end
nodes.title: Termination Procedures

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures for authorizing access to ePHI that are consistent with applicable requirements
nodes.title: Information Access Management

nodes.text: If a health care clearinghouse is part of a larger organization, implement policies to protect ePHI from unauthorized access by the larger organization
nodes.title: Isolating Health Care Clearinghouse Function

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures for granting access to ePHI
nodes.title: Access Authorization

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures that establish, document, review, and modify a user's right of access to ePHI
nodes.title: Access Establishment and Modification

nodes.text: Implement a security awareness and training program for all members of the workforce
nodes.title: Security Awareness and Training

nodes.text: Provide periodic security updates and reminders
nodes.title: Security Reminders

nodes.text: Implement procedures for guarding against, detecting, and reporting malicious software
nodes.title: Protection from Malicious Software

nodes.text: Implement procedures for monitoring log-in attempts and reporting discrepancies
nodes.title: Log-in Monitoring

nodes.text: Implement procedures for creating, changing, and safeguarding passwords
nodes.title: Password Management

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to address security incidents
nodes.title: Security Incident Procedures

nodes.text: Identify and respond to suspected or known security incidents; mitigate harmful effects; document incidents and outcomes
nodes.title: Response and Reporting

nodes.text: Establish and implement policies and procedures for responding to an emergency or other occurrence that damages systems containing ePHI
nodes.title: Contingency Plan

nodes.text: Establish and implement procedures to create and maintain retrievable exact copies of ePHI
nodes.title: Data Backup Plan

nodes.text: Establish and implement procedures to restore loss of data
nodes.title: Disaster Recovery Plan

nodes.text: Establish and implement procedures to enable continuation of critical business processes while operating in emergency mode
nodes.title: Emergency Mode Operation Plan

nodes.text: Implement procedures for periodic testing and revision of contingency plans
nodes.title: Testing and Revision Procedures

nodes.text: Assess the relative criticality of specific applications and data in support of other contingency plan components
nodes.title: Applications and Data Criticality Analysis

nodes.text: Perform a periodic technical and nontechnical evaluation based on standards implemented to assess security
nodes.title: Evaluation

nodes.text: Ensure business associates provide satisfactory assurances that they will appropriately safeguard ePHI
nodes.title: Business Associate Contracts and Other Arrangements

nodes.text: Document satisfactory assurances through written contracts that meet applicable requirements
nodes.title: Written Contract or Other Arrangement

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to limit physical access to electronic information systems and facilities while ensuring authorized access
nodes.title: Facility Access Controls

nodes.text: Establish procedures to allow facility access in support of data restoration under disaster recovery and emergency operations
nodes.title: Contingency Operations

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to safeguard the facility and equipment from unauthorized physical access, tampering, and theft
nodes.title: Facility Security Plan

nodes.text: Implement procedures to control and validate a person's access to facilities based on role or function
nodes.title: Access Control and Validation Procedures

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to document repairs and modifications to physical components of a facility related to security
nodes.title: Maintenance Records

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures that specify proper functions to be performed and the manner in which those functions are to be performed on workstations accessing ePHI
nodes.title: Workstation Use

nodes.text: Implement physical safeguards for all workstations that access ePHI to restrict access to authorized users
nodes.title: Workstation Security

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures that govern receipt and removal of hardware and electronic media containing ePHI
nodes.title: Device and Media Controls

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to address final disposition of ePHI and hardware or electronic media on which it is stored
nodes.title: Disposal

nodes.text: Implement procedures for removal of ePHI from electronic media before media are made available for re-use
nodes.title: Media Re-use

nodes.text: Maintain a record of movements of hardware and electronic media and any person responsible for movements
nodes.title: Accountability

nodes.text: Create a retrievable exact copy of ePHI before movement of equipment
nodes.title: Data Backup and Storage

nodes.text: Implement technical policies and procedures for systems that maintain ePHI to allow access only to authorized persons or software programs
nodes.title: Access Control

nodes.text: Assign a unique name and/or number for identifying and tracking user identity
nodes.title: Unique User Identification

nodes.text: Establish and implement procedures for obtaining necessary ePHI during an emergency
nodes.title: Emergency Access Procedure

nodes.text: Implement electronic procedures that terminate an electronic session after a predetermined time of inactivity
nodes.title: Automatic Logoff

nodes.text: Implement a mechanism to encrypt and decrypt ePHI
nodes.title: Encryption and Decryption

nodes.text: Implement hardware, software, and procedural mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems containing ePHI
nodes.title: Audit Controls

nodes.text: Implement policies and procedures to protect ePHI from improper alteration or destruction
nodes.title: Integrity

nodes.text: Implement electronic mechanisms to corroborate that ePHI has not been altered or destroyed in an unauthorized manner
nodes.title: Mechanism to Authenticate ePHI

nodes.text: Implement procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to ePHI is the one claimed
nodes.title: Person or Entity Authentication

nodes.text: Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized access to ePHI transmitted over electronic networks
nodes.title: Transmission Security

nodes.text: Implement security measures to ensure electronically transmitted ePHI is not improperly modified without detection
nodes.title: Integrity Controls

nodes.text: Implement a mechanism to encrypt ePHI whenever deemed appropriate
nodes.title: Encryption

nodes.text: Covered entities must have written contracts with business associates that ensure appropriate safeguards for ePHI
nodes.title: Business Associate Contracts or Other Arrangements

nodes.text: Group health plans must ensure plan documents incorporate provisions to establish permitted and required uses and disclosures of ePHI by plan sponsor
nodes.title: Requirements for Group Health Plans

nodes.text: Implement reasonable and appropriate policies and procedures to comply with standards, implementation specifications, or other requirements
nodes.title: Policies and Procedures

nodes.text: Maintain written policies and procedures, maintain documentation of actions, activities, or assessments required by this subpart in written or electronic form
nodes.title: Documentation

nodes.text: Retain documentation for 6 years from date of creation or last effective date, whichever is later
nodes.title: Time Limit

nodes.text: Make documentation available to those responsible for implementing procedures to which documentation pertains
nodes.title: Availability

nodes.text: Review documentation periodically and update as needed in response to environmental or operational changes
nodes.title: Updates

nodes.rationale: Both require identification and assessment of vulnerabilities and risks to information assets
Risk analysis requires assessment of potential impacts and likelihoods of threats
Risk analysis outcomes inform risk response prioritization
Risk management requires integration into enterprise risk management processes
Both require selection, prioritization, and tracking of risk responses
Risk management strategy includes establishing risk response options
Both require cybersecurity to be included in human resources practices including sanctions
Sanction policy is part of organizational cybersecurity policy enforcement
Both require monitoring of system activity through audit logs to find adverse events
Review of system activity logs enables analysis of potentially adverse events
Requires log records to be generated for continuous monitoring
Both require establishment of roles, responsibilities, and authorities for cybersecurity
Security official represents organizational leadership accountability for security risk
Both require access permissions to be defined, managed, and enforced following least privilege
Workforce security is part of HR practices for cybersecurity
Authorization procedures ensure appropriate access control
Supervision is part of establishing roles and responsibilities
Clearance procedures ensure workforce access appropriateness
Both require management of user identities and credentials throughout lifecycle including termination
Termination is part of HR cybersecurity practices
Both require policies for authorizing access based on principles of least privilege
Access management policy is part of cybersecurity policy
Both require procedures for granting and enforcing access authorizations
Both require procedures to establish, document, review and modify user access rights
Access management includes identity and credential management
Both require personnel awareness and training on cybersecurity risks
Training program should address specialized roles with security responsibilities
Both require prevention of unauthorized software installation and execution
Malware detection requires monitoring computing hardware and software
Both require monitoring personnel activity including login attempts
Password management is part of identity and credential management
Passwords are authentication mechanisms
Both require incident response plan execution when incidents are declared
Incident response plans must be established, communicated, and maintained
Both require incident report triage and validation
Both require analysis to establish what took place and root cause
Mitigation of harmful effects requires incident containment
Both require notification of stakeholders about incidents
Documentation of incidents requires recording investigation actions
Both require mechanisms to achieve resilience in adverse situations
Contingency plan execution supports recovery from incidents
Both require backups of data to be created, protected, maintained, and tested
Backup integrity must be verified before restoration
Both require recovery plan execution to restore operations
Both require restoration and verification of systems and services
Emergency operations require resilience mechanisms
Critical functions and risk management inform post-incident operations
Both require improvements from security tests and exercises
Both require evaluation and review of cybersecurity risk management performance
Evaluation identifies improvements from assessments
Both require cybersecurity roles and responsibilities with suppliers/partners to be established
Both require cybersecurity requirements to be integrated into contracts with third parties
Both require physical access to assets to be managed, monitored, and enforced
Facility protections help protect technology infrastructure from environmental threats
Both require configuration management practices for workstations
Workstation use policies are part of cybersecurity policy
Physical safeguards restrict workstation access to authorized users
Both require systems, hardware, software, and data to be managed throughout life cycles including disposal
Proper disposal protects confidentiality of data-at-rest
Media sanitization is part of lifecycle management
Both require technical access controls to enforce least privilege
Access control requires identity and credential management
Both require unique identification for users and services
Unique identification supports authentication
Emergency access procedures are part of access control policy
Both address encryption to protect confidentiality of data-at-rest
Both require log records to be generated for continuous monitoring
Audit controls enable monitoring of networks and systems for adverse events
Audit logs monitor personnel activity and technology usage
Both require protection of data integrity
Electronic mechanisms verify data has not been improperly altered
Both require authentication of users and services
Authentication requires identity proofing and binding to credentials
Both require protection of confidentiality and integrity of data-in-transit
Network protection helps secure data transmission
Both ensure transmitted data is not improperly modified
Encryption protects data-in-transit confidentiality
Both require cybersecurity policy to be established and enforced
Documentation supports policy implementation
Documentation of operational processes supports improvement identification

nodes.name: Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act
nodes.description: U.S. legislation to promote the adoption and meaningful use of health information technology.

nodes.heading: Definitions
nodes.text: Definitions related to HITECH privacy provisions

nodes.heading: Breach Notification
nodes.text: Notification in the case of breach of unsecured protected health information
Covered entities must notify affected individuals following a breach of unsecured ePHI.
Business associates must notify covered entities following a breach of unsecured ePHI.
Organizations must use statutory definitions of breach and unsecured ePHI for compliance purposes.
